definitions.definition: to look, smile, etc. in a particular direction

examples.text: She cast a welcoming smile in his direction.
I cast an angry look at him.
He groaned, casting his eyes to the ceiling.
She cast me a disapproving glance.

definitions.definition: to make light, a shadow, etc. appear in a particular place

examples.text: Someone was standing in the dark **shadow cast** by the light.
The moon had **cast** a silvery **light** on the huts.
The setting sun cast an orange glow over the mountains.

definitions.definition: to say, do or suggest something that makes people doubt something or think that somebody is less honest, good, etc.
definitions.sensetop: cast something on/upon somethingcast somethingcast something over somethingcast something into something

examples.text: This latest evidence **casts** serious **doubt** on his version of events.
‘You know that I'm not one to **cast aspersions**,’ she said.
The sad news cast a shadow over the proceedings *(= made people feel unhappy)*.
The entire economic future of the islands was cast into doubt.
Her aim was clearly to cast suspicion upon their motives.
The allegations are casting a cloud over his re-election campaign.
The incident had cast a pall over their preparations for the World Cup.

definitions.definition: to vote for somebody/something

examples.text: He refused to cast a vote for either candidate.
How many of the registered voters will actually cast their ballots?

definitions.definition: to choose actors to play the different parts in a film, play, etc.; to choose an actor to play a particular role

examples.text: The play is being cast in both the US and Britain.
She has cast him as an ambitious lawyer in her latest movie.

definitions.definition: to describe or present somebody/yourself in a particular way
definitions.sensetop: cast somebody/yourself as somethingcast somebody/yourself in something

examples.text: He cast himself as the innocent victim of a hate campaign.
The press were quick to cast her in the role of the ‘other woman’.

definitions.definition: to throw one end of a fishing line into a river, etc.
to throw somebody/something somewhere, especially using force

examples.text: The priceless treasures had been cast into the Nile.
They cast anchor at nightfall.

definitions.definition: when a snake casts its skin, the skin comes off as part of a natural process
if a horse casts a shoe, the shoe comes off by accident
to shape hot liquid metal, etc. by pouring it into a hollow container (called a mould)

examples.text: a statue cast in bronze
an artist **cast in the mould of** *(= very similar to)* Miró

definitions.definition: to look at or examine something quickly

examples.text: Could you just run your eyes over this report?
I cast my eyes around the room but couldn't see any familiar faces.

definitions.definition: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand

examples.text: Recent research has cast new light on the causes of the disease.

definitions.definition: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand

examples.text: Recent research has thrown new light on the causes of the disease.

definitions.definition: to make yourself think about something that happened in the past

examples.text: I want you to cast your minds back to the first time you met.

definitions.definition: to consider a lot of different people, activities, possibilities, etc. when you are looking for something

examples.text: It’s worth casting your net wide when applying for your first job.

definitions.definition: to use words that are thought to be magic and have the power to change or influence somebody/something
used to say that an event has happened or a decision has been made that cannot be changed

to use a method of choosing somebody/something that involves putting a number folded pieces of paper in a bag, one of them with a mark on it. People then take it in turns to take a piece of paper from the bag and the one who takes the paper with the mark on it is chosen.

examples.text: They drew lots for the right to go first.

definitions.definition: to stop caring about how dangerous something might be; to start taking risks

examples.text: He threw caution to the wind and dived into the water after the child.

wordOrigin: verb senses 1 to 7 and verb senses 10 to 11 Middle English: from Old Norse kasta ‘to cast or throw’. verb senses 8 to 9 mid 17th cent.: a special use of the original meaning of cast,in sense (11) of the verb.
